health care on the island is improving

this means less physicians available to

so what was the impact on healthcare so

islands hospitals operated without

did not have access to clean water and

there was a major community health
center called Hospital Costin yay that

this hurricane served as a catalyst for
many physicians who are considering
moving to the mainland to just pack up
and go so a significant percentage of
the physician workforce emigrated to the
mainland there ended up being a
nine-month wait time to see a specialist
and and 13-hour wait time for hospital

dire experience and after months in this

recognized that healthcare was going to

interoperability getting an established
established interoperable Network and
most importantly getting clinical data
in the cloud so let's break out the

Puerto Rico there were a couple pretty
fundamental issues that we still see
here in the u.s. that they experience
there where patient data is scattered in
bits and pieces across multiple
disparate IT systems fax was still the
standard by which providers exchange
medical information and providers need
access to an aggregated data set not
just to inform care but but also to get
paid if if they were at risk
so we established our first partnership
on the island with the Puerto Rico
Primary Care Association Network in 2017
and I'll refer to them as the pecan so
the pecan is a network of 20 federally
qualified health centers operating
ninety eight clinics across the island
geographically spread out so that
virtually everyone was in reach of a
clinic many clinics were actually mobile
clinics so they actually had wheels and
they would go to places where
traditional physical facilities did not
reach and they were responsible for the
care of 360,000 patients which is
roughly 10% of the island all of whom
were deeply impoverished underinsured
uninsured unstable housing in cases in
some cases homeless and and while the
population of the island was declining
the Pecan is actually reporting an
increase in inpatient volumes
so we partnered with them to implement
an interoperability engine for their
network of federally qualified health
centers that could accomplish a couple
things first we needed to aggregate the
comprehensive clinical history for every
patient second we needed to develop
reporting and analytics to improve
access to care to create really
actionable insights for providers and
third we needed to improve care
coordination across the clinics that
were a part of the Pecan network and
provide island-wide visibility for the
managing entity that was responsible for
public policy technical support and and
research opportunities so integrating
and normalizing clinical data is as
complicated as many of you know and so
we implemented a platform that could
integrate with their IT systems and
normalize data regardless of the format
whether it was hl7 JSON DICOM fire
virtually any data format and we
normalize it into a CCDA and then use an
algorithm to match different files to a
single patient then we'd store this data
and the data Lake and standardizing
standardizing the data set was the
really fundamental first step for
interoperability
and so there's a lot of work ahead to

the US Census projected a dramatic

so mostly Florida and New England the
reason I bring this up is because
patient movement and relocation after

often loses contact with their providers

and most importantly they lose their

so for someone with chronic disease it's

it's very fundamental information that

Network is is not just to inform patient
